title.narrative: Desk Study - Mtwara Generation and Transmission Development, through CORE International, Inc.

description.narrative: This desk study reviewed a proposal for a feasibility study to evaluate the technical, financial, and other aspects of developing generation and transmission infrastructure in southern Tanzania. The project involves the construction of two 200 megawatt gas-fired power plants and approximately 400 miles of transmission line in Tanzania's southern region.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

sector.narrative: Electric power transmission and distribution (centralised grids)

title.narrative: Desk Study - Pan-African Air Cargo Services, through Montgomery Consulting Group, Inc.

description.narrative: This $7,000 desk study reviewed a request for assistance from the Tanzanian company VIA Aviation (VIA) to fund a feasibility study (FS) for a proposed Pan-African Air Cargo (PAC) operation (Project) in Tanzania. The proposed FS would develop the requirements, specifications, and implementation roadmap for the PAC operation, and would also address technical, financial, regulatory, and other critical aspects of the proposed Project.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - U.S.-ACEF University of Dodoma 55 Megawatt Photovoltaic Solar Project, through Government of Tanzania

description.narrative: A USTDA grant of $600,000 to Tanzania's University of Dodoma (UDOM) is supporting a feasibility study to determine the technical, economic, and financial viability of implementing a combined 55 megawatt (MW) solar photovoltaic (PV) project on the university campus in the Tanzanian capital city of Dodoma (Project). The Project would include phased construction of three PV power plants (2 MW, 3 MW, and 50 MW installations) at sites located on the UDOM campus. Implementation of the Project would provide significant economic benefits for the University, diversify Tanzania's energy mix, lower fossil fuel consumption, and reduce associated greenhouse gas emissions. The Project would also increase access to power for UDOM and Tanzanians in the Dodoma region. The feasibility study is being undertaken on a sole-source basis by U.S. energy project developer, Hecate Energy LLC (Contractor). The Contractor has agreed to share the total feasibility study costs of $1,000,000.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - NextGen Solawazi Owners Engineer Project, through Government of Tanzania

description.narrative: This $200,000 grant to NextGen Solawazi is funding an owner's engineer that would evaluate the technical milestones related to implementing a five megawatt photovoltaic power project in Kigoma, Tanzania. This technical assistance (TA) includes an evaluation of the technical specifications of the project and will make recommendations for final project planning and preparation activities. The TA also includes monitoring and review of the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor selected to develop the Kigoma plant. The project will promote clean energy solutions in an underserved area of Tanzania.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - WASTE STREAM COMMERCIALIZATION, through Government of Tanzania

description.narrative: USTDA is providing a $299,780 grant to the Kilombero Sugar Factory for a feasibility study to determine the viability of producing ethanol and electricity. The feasibility study reviews the possibility of installing a distillation plant and provides a technical design; develops the optimal technical approach for the CHP plant; conducts an assessment of the local and international market for potable alcohol and fuel ethanol; and conducts an assessment of the viability of selling 40MW of excess power to the national grid.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - CAPACITY BUILDING FOR THE ENERGY AND WATER UTILITIES REGULATORY AUTHORITY, through Government of Tanzania

description.narrative: This Technical Assistance (TA) seeks to strengthen the institutional capacity of the Tanzanian Energy and Water Utilities Regulatory Authority (EWURA) in order to improve the enforcement of current regulatory policies and to increase the Agency's capacity to negotiate and adopt new regulations in the future. The TA will help EWURA establish a fair and transparent regulatory environment in Tanzania to create a level playing field for both public and private sector investments in the energy sector.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated end date is the latest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

sector.narrative: Democracy, Human Rights, and Governance - General
Public sector policy and administrative management

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - DAR ES SALAAM TO ISAKA RAILWAY, through Government of Tanzania

description.narrative: This $653,600 grant partially funds a study on the technical and financial feasibility of upgrading the 1,000 kilometer rail link from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania to Isaka, Tanzania from narrow gauge to AREMA standard gauge. The goal of the study is to improve rail service in Tanzania, promote the extension of rail service into land-locked Rwanda, and promote regional integration in transportation. This study promotes Trade Capacity Building by enhancing the movement of goods to and from the interior of Tanzania and port at Dar es Salaam.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Technical Assistance - BANK OF TANZANIA ICT MODERIZATION, through Government of Tanzania

description.narrative: This $498,000 for a Technical Assistance (TA) for the Bank of Tanzania (BOT) provides a roadmap for ICT modernization that will allow BOT to significantly increase its efficiency and effectiveness as it serves its critical role of maintaining price stability and carries out its other central banking functions.
